respect the results.[http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=54891&SelectRegion=Great_Lakes "DRC: Interview with Jacqueline Chenard, spokeswoman for MONUC in Kivu North"], ''[[IRIN]]'', 2006-07-30[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/7adfe242-2632-11db-afa1-0000779e2340.html "Congo’s rebel leader watches and waits"], ''[[Financial Times]]'', 2006-08-07[http://www.sabcnews.com/africa/central_africa/0,2172,137414,00.html "DRC rebel leader commits to peace"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929124117/http://www.sabcnews.com/africa/central_africa/0,2172,137414,00.html |date=29 September 2007 }}, ''[[South African Broadcasting Corporation|SABC]]'', 2006-10-27 On 25 November, however, a day before the Supreme Court ruled that [[Joseph Kabila]] had won the presidential election's second round, Nkunda's forces undertook [[Democratic Republic of the Congo general election, 2006#Offensive by Nkunda in Sake|a sizeable offensive]] in Sake against the DRC army 11th Brigade,[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/26/AR2006112600031.html "Congo Warlord's Fighters Attack Forces"], ''[[Washington Post]]'', 2006-11-26 also clashing with MONUC peacekeepers.[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L26775091.htm "UN says engages rebels as army flees Congo town"], [[Reuters]], 2006-11-26 The attack may not have been related to the election but due to the "killing of a Tutsi civilian who was close to one of the commanders in this group." The UN called on the DRC government to negotiate with Nkunda, and DRC Interior Minister, General [[Denis Kalume]], was sent to eastern DRC to begin negotiations.[http://www.voanews.com/english/2006-11-27-voa27.cfm "UN Calls for Negotiations in Eastern DRC"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214000807/http://voanews.com/english/2006-11-27-voa27.cfm |date=14 December 2006 }}, ''[[Voice of America]]'', 2006-11-27 On 2006-12-07, RCD-Goma troops attacked DRC army positions in Nord Kivu. With military assistance from MONUC, the DRC army was reported to have regained their positions, with about 150 RCD-Goma forces having been killed. Approximately 12,000 Congolese civilians have fled the DRC to [[Kisoro District]], Uganda.[http://somalinet.com/news/world/Africa/5550 "DRC: 12,000 Congolese flee into Uganda"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023172157/http://somalinet.com/news/world/Africa/5550 |date=23 October 2007 }}, ''SomaliNet News'', 2006-12-08 Also on that day, a rocket fired from the DRC to the Kisoro District killed seven people.[http://somalinet.com/news/world/Africa/5515 "DRC: Rocket kills 7 in Uganda"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023172152/http://somalinet.com/news/world/Africa/5515 |date=23 October 2007 }}, ''SomaliNet News'', 2006-12-07 ===2007=== In early 2007, the central DRC government attempted to reduce the threat posed by Nkunda by trying to integrate his troops further into the [[FARDC]], the national armed forces, in what was called a 'mixage' process.[http://www.issafrica.org/dynamic/administration/file_manager/file_links/DDR%20IN%20DRC%20SITREP.PDF Henri Boshoff "The DDR Process in the DRC: A Never-Ending Story"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216023854/http://www.issafrica.org/dynamic/administration/file_manager/file_links/DDR%20IN%20DRC%20SITREP.PDF |date=16 February 2008 }}, Institute for Security Studies, 2007-07-02 However, this backfired and it now appears that from about January to August Nkunda controlled five brigades of troops rather than two. On 24 July 2007, the UN peacekeeping head [[Jean-Marie Guehenno]] stated, "Mr Nkunda's forces are the single most serious threat to stability in the DR Congo."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6913498.stm "Rogue general threatens DRC peace"] ''BBC News Africa'' 2007-07-24 In early September, Nkunda's forces had a smaller DRC force under siege in [[Masisi]], and MONUC helicopters were ferrying government soldiers to relieve the town. Scores of men were reported killed, and another major conflict was in progress.{{cite news| url= https://www.theguardian.com/congo/story/0,,2161241,00.html | title = Fear of fresh conflict in Congo as renegade general turns guns on government forces| author = Chris McGreal| publisher = The Guardian| date= 3 September 2007| accessdate = 3 September 2007| location = London}} On 5 September 2007, after the government FARDC forces claimed they had used a [[Mil Mi-24]] helicopter gunship to kill 80 of Nkunda's rebels, Nkunda called on the government to return to a peace process. "It's the government side who have broken the peace process. We are asking the government to get back on the peace process, because it is the real way to resolve the Congolese problem", he said[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6979375.stm "DRC rebel general calls for peace"] ''BBC News Africa'' 2007-09-05 In September, Nkunda's men "raided ten secondary schools and four primary schools where they took the children by force in order to make them join their ranks." According to United Nations officials, girls were taken as sex slaves, boys were used as fighters, in violation of international law.[http://www.smh.com.au/news/World/Congo-warlord-continues-to-recruit-kids/2007/09/20/1189881644788.html "Congo warlord continues to recruit kids."] ''Sydney Morning Herald'' website, 2007-09-20. Following the date of the UN report, thousands more Congolese fled their homes for displaced persons camps.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7009442.stm "Congolese flee renegade general"], ''BBC News Africa'', 23 September 2007 The government set a 15 October 2007 deadline for Nkunda's troops to begin disarming. This deadline passed without action and, on 17 October, President [[Joseph Kabila]] ordered the [[Military of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|military]] to prepare to disarm Nkunda's forces forcibly. Government forces advanced on the Nkunda stronghold of [[Kichanga]]. Thousands of civilians fleeing the fighting between Nkunda and government-allied [[Mai-Mai]] around [[Bunagana, Democratic Republic of the Congo|Bunagana]] arrived in [[Rutshuru]] several days later. There were separate reports of government troops engaging units under Nkunda around Bukima, near Bunagana, as well as some refugees fleeing across the border into Uganda. The number of people displaced by the fighting since the beginning of the year was estimated at over 370,000.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7054699.stm "Thousands flee amid Congo clashes"], ''BBC News Africa'', 2007-10-20 In early November 2007, Nkunda's troops captured the town of [[Nyanzale]], about {{convert|100|km|mi}} north of Goma. Three neighbouring villages were also reported captured, and the army outpost abandoned.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7124279.stm "DR Congo rebels take eastern town"], ''BBC News Africa'', 2007-12-03 A government offensive in early December resulted in the capture by the 82nd Brigade of the town of Mushake, overlooking a key road (however, Reuters reports a FARDC integrated brigade, the 14th, took the town).Joe Bavier, [http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L0519502.htm "Congo army says retakes eastern town from rebels"], 2007-12-05 This followed a statement by the [[United Nations Mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo]] that it would be willing to offer artillery support to the government offensive. In a regional conference held in [[Addis Ababa]], the United States, Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda pledged to support the Congolese government and not support "negative forces", widely seen as code for Nkunda's forces.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7128367.stm "Army seizes DR Congo rebel base"], ''BBC News'', 5 December 2007 Nkunda stated on 14 December 2007 that he was open to peace talks.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7145415.stm "DR Congo rebel 'ready for peace'"] ''BBC News Africa'' 2007-12-14 The government called such talks on 20 December to be held from 27 December 2007 to 5 January 2008.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7150248.stm "DR Congo invites rebels to talks"] ''BBC News Africa'' 2007-12-20 These talks were then postponed to be held from 6 to 14 January 2008.[http://allafrica.com/stories/200712280775.html Sylvie Van Den Wildenberg "Congo-Kinshasa: Launching of Preparatory Work for Kivus Peace Conference"] ''United Nations Mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo'' 2007-12-28 ===January 2008 peace deal=== Nkunda's group did attend the talks, but walked out on 10 January 2008, after an alleged attempted arrest of one of their members.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7181633.stm|title=Rebels resume Congo peace talks|publisher=BBC|date=11 January 2008|accessdate=2008-11-27}} They later returned to the talks.{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hb8U-Nk6sFpGSY-i5PYCI9KanQGA |title=Nkunda's team to return to DR Congo peace conference |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=10 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520185532/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hb8U-Nk6sFpGSY-i5PYCI9KanQGA |archivedate=20 May 2011 |df= }} The talks' schedule was extended to last until 21 January 2008,[https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=25340&Cr=Democratic&Cr1=Congo "UN-backed summit in DR Congo discusses amnesty for dissident general"] ''UN News Centre'' 2008-01-18 and then to 22 January 2008 as an agreement appeared to be within reach.[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5git8KO5XNzad5KRJYPSi4eBTIrHw "Armed groups in east DR Congo ready for ceasefire"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520185556/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5git8KO5XNzad5KRJYPSi4eBTIrHw |date=20 May 2011 }} ''Agence France Press'' 2008-01-21 It was further extended to 23 January 2008 over final disagreements regarding war crimes cases.[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5j_TQxl92l7dVUv7cKAhaEqOQLUeA "Row over war crimes status delays end of DR Congo conference"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520185625/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5j_TQxl92l7dVUv7cKAhaEqOQLUeA |date=20 May 2011 }} ''Agence France Press'' 2008-01-22 The peace deal was signed on 23 January 2008 and included provisions for an immediate ceasefire, the phased withdrawal of all rebel forces in North Kivu province, the resettlement of thousands of villagers, and immunity for Nkunda's forces.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7204898.stm|title=Eastern Congo peace deal signed|publisher=BBC|date=23 January 2008|accessdate=2008-11-27}} The agreement encouraged FARDC and the United Nations to remove FDLR forces from Kivu. Dissatisfaction with progress and lack of resettlement of refugees caused the CNDP forces to declare war on the FDLR and hostilities to resume,[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=96187980 As Congo Rebels Advance, Civilians Target U.N.]. All Things Considered, National Public Radio. 27 October 2008. including civilian atrocities.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200805140953.html |title=After Two Key Deals, What Progress Towards Peace in North Kivu?|publisher=Allafrica.com|accessdate=15 October 2014}} Neither the [[Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda]] nor the [[Rwanda]]n government took part in the talks, a fact which may hurt the stability of the agreement.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7206720.stm "Rebels 'threaten DR Congo deal'"] ''BBC News Africa'' 2008-01-24[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7206823.stm "Is this peace for eastern DR Congo?"] ''BBC News Africa'' 2008-01-24 ===Fall 2008 fighting=== {{Main|2008 Nord-Kivu war}} On 26 October 2008 Nkunda's rebels seized a major military camp, along with [[Virunga National Park]] for use as a base to launch attacks from. This occurred after the peace treaty failed, with the resultant fighting displacing thousands.{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/10/26/congo.gorillapark/index.html#cnnSTCText |title=Thousands flee fighting as Congo rebels seize gorilla park |publisher=CNN |date=26 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-28}} The park was taken due to its strategic location on a main road leading to the city of [[Goma]]. On 27 October riots began around the United Nations compound in Goma, and civilians pelted the building with rocks and threw [[Molotov cocktail]]s, claiming that the UN forces had done nothing to prevent the rebel advance.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/10/27/congo.united.nations.ap/index.html#cnnSTCText |title=Protesters attack U.N. HQ in eastern Congo |publisher=CNN |date=24 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030045606/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/10/27/congo.united.nations.ap/index.html |archivedate=30 October 2008 }} The Congolese national army also retreated under pressure from the rebel army in a "major retreat". [[Attack helicopter]]s and [[Armoured fighting vehicle|armoured vehicles]] of [[MONUC|UN peacekeepers]] (MONUC) were used in an effort to halt the advance of the rebels, who claim to be within 7 miles (11 kilometres) of Goma.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/10/27/congo.united.nations/index.html |title=U.N. gunships battle rebels in east Congo |publisher=CNN |date=28 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029024104/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/10/27/congo.united.nations/index.html |archivedate=29 October 2008 }} Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General for DRC [[Alan Doss]] explained the necessity of engaging the rebels, stating that "...[the UN] can't allow population centers to be threatened... [the UN] had to engage."{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7692932.stm|title=UN joins battle with Congo rebels|publisher=BBC|date=27 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-28}} On 28 October, rebels and combined government-MONUC troops battled between the Kibumba refugee camp and [[Rutshuru]]. Five [[Rocket-propelled grenade|rockets]] were fired at a convoy of UN vehicles protecting a road to the territorial capital of [[Rutshuru]], hitting two [[armoured personnel carrier]]s. The APCs, which contained [[Indian Army]] troops, were relatively undamaged, though a Lieutenant Colonel and two other personnel were injured.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/10/30/stories/2008103055851200.htm|title=Armymen hurt in Congo|work=[[The Hindu]]|date=30 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-31}} Rebel forces later captured the town. Meanwhile, civilians continued to riot, at some points pelting retreating Congolese troops with rocks, though UN spokeswoman Sylvie van den Wildenberg stated that the UN has "reinforced [their] presence" in the region.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/10/28/congo.fighting/index.html#cnnSTCText|title=Thousands flee rebel advance in Congo|publisher=CNN|date=28 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-28}} On 29 October the rebels declared a unilateral ceasefire as they approached Goma, though they still intended to take the city.{{cite news |first=Catherine |last=Philp |title=UN peacekeepers braced for full-scale war in central Africa |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article5043727.ece?token=null&offset=0&page=1 |publisher=The Times |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-30 | location=London}} That same day a French request for an EU reinforcement of 1,500 troops was refused by several countries and appeared unlikely to materialise; however, the UN forces in place stated they would act to prevent takeovers of population centres.{{cite news |first=Michelle |last=Faul |title= Congo rebels reach Goma edge, declare cease-fire |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hoitt5BsM5OKJ2Mmc3g5q6iufXjwD944CKL83 |agency=Associated Press |date=29 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-29}}{{dead link|date=November 2012|bot=Legobot}} Throughout the day the streets of the city were filled with refugees and fleeing troops, including their tanks and other military vehicles. There were also reports of looting and commandeering of cars by Congolese troops.{{cite news |first=Jeffrey |last=Gettleman |title=Many Flee as Congo Rebels Approach Eastern City |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/30/world/africa/30congo.html?ref=africa |work=The New York Times |date=29 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-29}} That night the UN Security Council unanimously adopted a non-binding resolution which condemned the recent rebel advance and demanded it be halted.{{cite news |title=Le Conseil de sécurité condamne l'avancée des rebelles dans l'est de la RDC |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/web/depeches/0,14-0,39-37447239@7-37,0.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081102074633/http://www.lemonde.fr/web/depeches/0,14-0,39-37447239@7-37,0.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 November 2008 |work=Le Monde |language=French |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-30 }} Despite the ceasefire, World Vision workers had to flee to the Rwandan border to work, and shots were still fired. The [[United States Department of State]] sent [[Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs]] [[Jendayi Frazer]] as an envoy to the region.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/10/29/congo.fighting/index.html|title=Congo rebels declare cease-fire to prevent panic|publisher=CNN|date=30 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-30}} On 30 October looting and violence by Congolese soldiers, some of them drunk, continued in Goma, though contingents of other troops and paramilitary police attempted to contain the looting by patrolling the streets in pick-up trucks.{{cite news |first=Patrick |last=Barth |title=Drunk and in retreat, troops unleash wave of death on their own people |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article5051307.ece |work=The Times |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-30 | location=London}} Nkunda called for direct talks with the Congolese government,{{cite news|title=Rebels call for talks in Congo |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/rebels-call-for-talks-in-congo-14023545.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120721184149/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/rebels-call-for-talks-in-congo-14023545.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 July 2012 |work=Belfast Telegraph |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-30 }} also stating that he would take Goma "if there is no ceasefire, no security and no advance in the peace process."{{cite news |first=Yves |last=Boussen |title=Congo rebels warn of city occupation |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/congo-rebels-warn-of-city-occupation-980266.html |work=The Independent |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-30}} On 31 October Nkunda declared that he would create a "[[humanitarian corridor|humanitarian aid corridor]]", a no-fire zone where displaced persons would be allowed back to their homes, given the consent of the United Nations task force in the Congo. Working with the UN forces around Goma, Nkunda hoped to relocate victims of the recent fighting between his CNDP forces and UN peacekeepers. MONUC spokesman Kevin Kennedy stated that MONUC's forces were stretched thin trying to keep peace within and around the city; recent looting by Congolese soldiers had made it harder to do so as incidents arose both within city limits and outside. According to [[Anneke Van Woudenberg]], a [[Human Rights Watch]] researcher, more than 20 people were killed overnight in Goma alone. Meanwhile, Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] contacted Rwandan President Paul Kagame to discuss a long-term solution.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/10/30/congo.rebel/index.html|title=Rebel general offers aid corridor for Congo|publisher=CNN|date=31 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-31}} Also on 31 October British Foreign Minister [[David Miliband]] and French Foreign Minister [[Bernard Kouchner]] flew to the region, with the intention of stopping in Kinshasa, Goma, and possibly Kigali.{{cite news|last=Sturcke|first=James|title=David Miliband holds talks with Congolese president|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/nov/01/david-miliband-talks-kinshasa-congo|accessdate=30 January 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=1 November 2008}} On 6 November rebels broke the ceasefire and wrested control of another town in eastern [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] in clashes with government forces on the eve of a regional summit on the crisis. [[National Congress for the Defence of the People]] (CNDP) rebels seized control of the centre of [[Nyanzale]], an important army base in [[Nord-Kivu]] province after government forces fled. Residents reported that rebels had shot dead civilians suspected of supporting pro-government militia.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7713758.stm|title=Congolese rebels make new gains|date=6 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-07|work=BBC News}} ===Angolan involvement=== In November 2008, during the clashes around Goma, a UN source reported that [[Angola]]n troops were seen taking part in combat operations alongside government forces. Kinshasa repeatedly denied that foreign troops were on its soil — an assertion echoed by the UN mission, which has 17,000 blue-helmeted peacekeepers on the ground. There is "military cooperation" between Congo and Angola, and that "there are perhaps Angolan (military) instructors in country", according to the UN. Angola, a former Portuguese colony, sided with [[Kinshasa]] in the 1998–2003 Second Congo War that erupted when Democratic Republic of Congo was in a massive rebellion.{{cite web|title=Congo War|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/congo.htm|work=GlobalSecurity.org|accessdate=30 January 2012}} ===Capture of Nkunda and peace treaty=== On 22 January 2009, the Rwandan military, during a joint operation with the Congolese Army, captured Nkunda as he fled from DR Congo into neighbouring Rwanda.BBC News. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7846339.stm Rwanda arrests Congo rebel leader]. 23 January 2009 Rwandan officials have yet to say if he will be handed over to DR Congo, which has issued an international warrant for his arrest. A military spokesperson said Nkunda had been seized after sending three battalions to repel an advance by a joint Congolese-Rwandan force.{{cite web|url=http://www.zimdaily.com/news/nkunda27.6814.html|title=Rebel leader General Nkunda arrested|date=23 January 2009|accessdate=2009-01-23|work=The Zim Daily}} The force was part of a joint Congolese-Rwandan operation which was launched to hunt Rwandan Hutu militiamen operating in DR Congo.{{cite web|url=http://www.africa-times-news.com/2009/01/congo-rebel-leader-nkunda-arrested/ |title=Congo, rebel leader Nkunda arrested |date=23 January 2009 |accessdate=2009-01-23 |work=Africa Times |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212225335/http://www.africa-times-news.com/2009/01/congo-rebel-leader-nkunda-arrested/ |archivedate=12 February 2009 |df= }} Nkunda is currently being held at an undisclosed location in Rwanda.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0123/congo.html|title=Congo's Nkunda arrested in Rwanda|date=23 January 2009|accessdate=2009-01-23|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}} A Rwandan military spokesman has claimed, however, that Nkunda is being held at [[Gisenyi]], a city in [[Rubavu]] district in the [[Western Province, Rwanda|Western Province]] of Rwanda.{{cite web|url=http://www.eleconomista.es/mundo/noticias/989692/01/09/Congo-rebel-leader-Nkunda-arrested.html|title=Congo rebel leader Nkunda arrested|date=23 January 2009|accessdate=2009-01-23|work=[[El Economista (Spain)|el Economista]]}} DR Congo's government suggested his capture would end the activities of one of the country's most feared rebel groups, recently split by a leadership dispute.{{cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle08.asp?xfile=data/international/2009/January/international_January1240.xml§ion=international |title=Congo rebel leader Nkunda arrested in Rwanda |date=23 January 2009 |accessdate=2009-01-23 |work=[[Khaleej Times]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608193800/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle08.asp?xfile=data%2Finternational%2F2009%2FJanuary%2Finternational_January1240.xml§ion=international |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df= }} With the ending of the joint Rwandan-DROC offensive against Hutu militiamen responsible for the [[Rwandan Genocide|1994 Genocide in Rwanda]], the Kivu conflict effectively ended.Militiamen later surrender.[https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20090225/wl_africa_afp/drcongorwandaunrestrebels;_ylt=AlRNLdYsYPim8xnwuZ_rNDhvaA8F ]{{dead link|date=November 2012}} On 23 March 2009, the NCDP signed a peace treaty with the government, in which it agreed to become a political party in exchange for the release of its members. ===May 2009 FDLR attacks=== Over the weekend of 9/10 May 2009, [[Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda|FDLR]] Rwandan Hutu rebels were blamed for attacks on the villages of Ekingi and Busurungi in Congo's eastern [[South Kivu]] province.{{cite news|title='Dozens killed' in DR Congo raids|publisher=BBC|date=13 May 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8049105.stm|accessdate= 14 May 2009}} More than 90 people were killed at Ekingi, including 60 civilians and 30 government troops, and "dozens more" were said to be killed at Busurungi. The FDLR were blamed by the United Nations' [[Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]]; the UN's peacekeeping force, [[United Nations Mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo|MONUC]], and the [[Military of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congolese Army]] investigated the attacks. The FDLR had attacked several other villages in the preceding weeks and clashes occurred between FDLR forces and the Congolese Army, during which government forces are reported to have lost men.{{cite news|title=Dozens of civilians killed in DRCongo rebel attacks: UN| agency=Associated Press|date=13 May 2009|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iEw4rts174XhpU0NaFtFR-LB2zSw| accessdate = 14 May 2009}} The most recent attacks had forced a significant number of people from their homes in Busurungi to Hombo, {{convert|20|km|mi}} north. The Congolese Army and MONUC were planning operations in South Kivu to eliminate the FDLR. ===2010 attacks=== On 18 August, three Indian UN soldiers were killed by Mai-Mai rebels in a surprise attack at a MONUSCO base in Kirumba, Nord-Kivu. On 23 October, Mai-Mai rebels attacked a MONUSCO base in Rwindi ({{convert|30|km|abbr=on|disp=or}} north of Kirumba). UN troops killed 8 rebels in the battle.AFP (25 October 2010). [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hv7j24ojTQkSODlC0LWLYNM_oUCA?docId=CNG.054898c0f8f960a17b20c59c1f5d54e6.a11 UN peacekeepers in DR Congo repel attack.] Retrieved 2 April 2012. ===M23 rebellion=== {{main|M23 rebellion}} [[File:M23 withdrawl from Goma.PNG|thumb|M23 rebels withdraw from Goma after it captured the city in November 2012.]] In March 2009, the CNDP had signed a peace treaty with the government, in which it agreed to become a political party in exchange for the release of its imprisoned members.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j-U_1NZdVdXyssb9DPt47IHx7j7Q "DR Congo government, CNDP rebels 'sign peace deal'"], ''AFP'', 24 March 2009 In April 2012, former [[National Congress for the Defence of the People]] (CNDP) soldiers mutinied against the government. The mutineers formed a rebel group called the [[March 23 Movement]] (M23). Former CNDP commander [[Bosco Ntaganda]], known as "the Terminator" is accused of founding the movement.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/video/africa/2012/05/20125181131799659.html |title=DR Congo troops shell rebel bases — Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2012-11-21}} On 4 April, it was reported that Ntaganda and 300 loyal troops defected from the DRC and clashed with government forces in the [[Rutshuru]] region north of [[Goma]].{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201204040870.html|title=Congo-Kinshasa: General Ntaganda and Loyalists Desert Armed Forces|publisher=Allafrica.com|accessdate=15 October 2014}} [[Africa Confidential]] said on 25 May 2012 that "the revolt now seems to be as much about resisting an attempt by Kinshasa to disrupt CNDP networks in the restive Kivu provinces, a process of which Ntaganda may find himself a casualty."'Rwanda looms larger in Kivu,' AC, 25 May 2012 On 20 November 2012, the M23 took control of Goma after the national army retreated westward. [[MONUSCO]], the United Nations peacekeeping force, watched the takeover without intervening, stating that its mandate allowed it only to protect civilians.{{cite web|author=Pete Jones and David Smith |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/nov/20/goma-falls-congo-rebels |title=Goma falls to Congo rebels |work=The Guardian |date=20 November 2012 |accessdate=20 November 2012 |archivedate=21 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CKWRqcSg?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/nov/20/goma-falls-congo-rebels |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news|author=Jonny Hogg |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/20/us-congo-democratic-idUSBRE8AI0UO20121120 |title=Congo rebels seize eastern city as U.N. forces look on |agency=Reuters |date=20 November 2012 |accessdate=20 November 2012 |archivedate=21 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CKWVRWf1?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/20/us-congo-democratic-idUSBRE8AI0UO20121120 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} M23 withdrew from Goma in early December following negotiations with the government and regional powers.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20565711|title=Rebels in DR Congo withdraw from Goma|date=18 December 2012 |publisher=BBC News |access-date=10 December 2012}} On 24 February 2013, leaders of 11 African nations signed an agreement designed to bring peace to the eastern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo.{{cite news|title=African leaders sign deal aimed at peace in eastern Congo|agency=Reuters|date=24 February 2013|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/25/congo-democratic-un-idUSL6N0BO16X20130225|accessdate=25 February 2013}} The M23 rebels were not represented in the deal's negotiations or at the signing. Following disagreements in the M23 about how to react to the peace agreements, M23 political coordinator [[Jean-Marie Runiga Lugerero]], was sacked by its military chief [[Sultani Makenga]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21642301|title=DR Congo: Army 'seizes' eastern towns held by M23 rebels|publisher=bbcnews.com|access-date= 3 March 2013|date=2 March 2013}} Makenga declared himself interim leader and clashes between those loyal to him and those loyal to Jean-Marie Runiga Lugerero, who is allied with Bosco Ntaganda, have killed ten men and two others were hospitalised.{{cite news|title=Clashes among DR Congo rebels leave 10 dead |agency=AFP |work=Global Post |date=25 February 2013 |url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130225/clashes-among-dr-congo-rebels-leave-10-dead-hospital |accessdate=25 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225192354/http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130225/clashes-among-dr-congo-rebels-leave-10-dead-hospital |archivedate=25 February 2013 |df=dmy }} In March 2013, the United Nations [[Security Council]] authorized the deployment of an intervention brigade within MONUSCO to carry out targeted offensive operations, with or without the [[Military of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congolese national army]], against armed groups that threaten peace in eastern DRC.{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=44876#.UizEW9JJOE0|title=Tanzanian troops arrive in eastern DR Congo as part of UN intervention brigade|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=8 September 2013|date=10 May 2013}} It is the first peacekeeping unit tasked with carrying out offensive operations. === March 2013: MONUSCO Mandate for a Rapid Intervention Brigade === [[File:Photo of the Day, 08 January 2014.jpg|thumb|MONUSCO peacekeepers of the North Kivu brigade on patrol in a street of Goma pass a group of teenagers returning from a football game.]] {{main|United Nations Force Intervention Brigade}} On 28 March 2013, faced with recurrent waves of conflict in eastern DRC threatening the overall stability and development of the country and wider [[Great Lakes region]], the [[Security Council]] decided, by its resolution 2098, to create a specialized “intervention brigade” for an initial period of one year and within the authorized [[MONUSCO]] troop ceiling of 19,815. It would consist of three infantry battalions, one artillery and one special force and reconnaissance company and operate under direct command of the [[MONUSCO Force Commander]], with the responsibility of neutralizing armed groups and the objective of contributing to reducing the threat posed by armed groups to state authority and civilian security in eastern DRC and to make space for stabilization activities. The Council also decided that MONUSCO shall strengthen the presence of its military, police and civilian components in eastern DRC and reduce, to the fullest extent possible for the implementation of its mandate, its presence in areas not affected by conflict in particular [[Kinshasa]] and in western DRC.{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/missions/monusco/mandate.shtml|title=MONUSCO Mandate - United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|publisher=Un.org|accessdate=15 October 2014}} The last batch of the Malawi troops committed to the MONUSCO [[United Nations Force Intervention Brigade|Force Intervention Brigade]] arrived in Goma, North Kivu province, on 7 October 2013. They will be part of the 3000- strong force to which Tanzania and South Africa are the other two troop contributing countries.{{CN|date=December 2017}} Since the arrival of its first troops in June 2013, the Intervention Brigade has already gone into action resulting in the withdrawal of M23, {{convert|30|km|mi}} from its initial positions in [[Kanyaruchinya]], on 31 August 2013.{{CN|date=December 2017}} The Intervention Brigade is now at its full strength with the arrival of the Malawi infantry battalion. Tanzania, South Africa and Malawi have been picked for the UN Stabilization Mission in DR Congo (MONUSCO) because of the wide experience they gained in other UN Peacekeeping missions. For instance, 95 percent of the Malawi troops have been already in peacekeeping missions in Kosovo, Liberia, Rwanda, Sudan, and they are well prepared to face any operational challenges.{{cite web|url=http://monusco.unmissions.org/Default.aspx?tabid=10662&ctl=Details&mid=14594&ItemID=20212&language=en-US|title=Last batch of Malawi troops now in Goma for the UN Force Intervention Brigade|publisher=Monusco.unmissions.org|accessdate=15 October 2014}} ===2015 resurgence=== [[File:KitshangaWar-11 (8539323200).jpg|thumb|left|Destruction in the town of [[Kitshanga]] caused by fighting between FARDC and APCLS rebels in 2013]] In January 2015, it was reported that UN and Congo troops were preparing an offensive on FDLR in the Kivu region, while striking [[National Forces of Liberation|FNL-Nzabampema]] positions on Eastern Congo on January 5, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/un-congo-prepar-offensive-against-fdlr-rebels/2586565.html|title=UN, Congo Prepare Offensive Against FDLR Rebels|work=VOA|accessdate=22 January 2015}} Several days earlier an infiltration by an unknown rebel group from Eastern Congo to Burundi left 95 rebels and 2 Burundi soldiers dead. On 13 January 2015, the Congolese military held a press conference announcing the destruction of four of the 20 militant factions operating in South Kivu. The Raïa Mutomboki armed group will undergo disarmament. A total of 39 rebels were killed and 24 captured since the start of the Sokola 2 operation in October 2014, 55 weapons and large quantities of ammunition were also seized. FARDC casualties amounted to 8 killed and 4 wounded.{{cite web|url=http://radiookapi.net/actualite/2015/01/13/sud-kivu-4-des-20-groupes-armes-completement-demanteles-selon-les-fardc/|title=Sud-Kivu: 4 des 20 groupes armés "complètement démantelés", selon les FARDC|work=Radio Okapi|date=13 January 2015|accessdate=23 January 2015}} On 25 January 2015, 85 Raïa Mutomboki rebels surrendered to the authorities in the town of [[Mubambiro]], North Kivu; the former militants will be gradually integrated into FARDC. Earlier in January, Raïa Mutomboki, founder Nyanderema, approached the town of [[Luizi]] with a group of 9 fighters, announcing their abandonment of armed struggle. 24 rifles, 2 grenades and other military equipment was transferred to FARDC during the two incidents.{{cite web|url=http://radiookapi.net/actualite/2015/01/25/sud-kivu-85-raia-mukombozi-se-rendent-aux-fardc/|title=Sud-Kivu: 85 Raïa Mukombozi se rendent aux FARDC|work=Radio Okapi|date=25 January 2015|accessdate=28 January 2015}} On January 31, the DRC troops launched a campaign against the FDLR [[Hutu]] rebels.{{cite web | url=https://news.yahoo.com/dr-congo-says-offensive-against-hutu-rebels-underway-161230672.html | title=DR Congo says offensive against Hutu rebels underway | date=31 January 2015 | accessdate=1 February 2015}} On 13 March 2015, a military spokesman announced that a total of 182 FDLR rebels were killed since the start of the January offensive. Large amounts of weaponry and ammunition were seized, as the army recaptured the towns of Kirumba Kagondo, Kahumiro, Kabwendo, Mugogo, Washing 1 and 2, Kisimba 1, 2 and 3, among other locales.{{cite web|url=http://radiookapi.net/actualite/2015/03/14/traque-contre-les-fdlr-environ-182-rebelles-neutralises-au-nord-sud-kivu/|title=Traque contre les FDLR: environ 182 rebelles neutralisés au Nord et Sud-Kivu|work=Radio Okapi|date=13 March 2015|accessdate=15 March 2015}} In January 2016, fighting broke out between the FDLR, ADF and Mai-Mai militias, which resulted in thousands fleeing to surrounding areas in North Kivu's Goma .{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/56ab5d576.html|title=Fighting in eastern DRC forces thousands to flee|work=News Stories|date=29 January 2016|accessdate=26 February 2016}} ===2017 war=== Approximately 1.7 million were forced to flee their homes in the DR Congo in 2017 as a result of intensified fighting. Ulrika Blom, a relief worker from Norway, has noted the magnitude of the refugee crisis by comparing the numbers to Yemen, Syria, and Iraq. On December 7, 2017, an [[2017 Semuliki attack|attack]] orchestrated by the [[Allied Democratic Forces]] on a UN base in the [[North Kivu]] region resulted in the death of at least 15 UN peacekeepers from the [[MONUSCO]] mission. This attack drew international criticism, with [[UN Secretary-General]] [[Antonio Guterres]] describing the incident, the worst altercation involving peacekeepers in recent history, as a "war crime".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-42285871|title=UN peacekeepers killed in DR Congo|date=8 December 2017|publisher=|access-date=10 December 2017|via=www.BBC.com}} The assault, in terms of fatalities, was the most severe suffered by peacekeepers since an ambush in Somalia in 1993. The peacekeeping regiment that came under attack was composed of troops from [[Tanzania]]. In addition to the peacekeepers, five soldiers from the [[Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|FARDC]] were killed in the attack.{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2017/1208/926002-peacekeepers/|title=At least 14 UN peacekeepers killed in Congo attack|date=8 December 2017|website=RTE.ie|access-date=10 December 2017}} Analysts felt that the size and scale of the attack was unprecedented, but that it represented another step in the conflict which has been prevalent in the region for many years.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/12/08/u-n-peacekeepers-were-killed-in-congo-heres-what-we-know/|title=Analysis - U.N. peacekeepers were killed in Congo. Here’s what we know.|first=Christoph|last=Vogel|date=8 December 2017|publisher=|access-date=10 December 2017|via=www.WashingtonPost.com}} The motivation for the attack was unknown, but it was expected to further destabilise the region. The Congolese forces claimed that the [[Islamist]] ADF lost 72 militants in the attack, raising the total number of fatalities in excess of 90. ==Human rights abuses== ===Child recruitment by the armed groups=== {{main|Child soldiers in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} Violence is widespread: "In Masisi 99.1% (897/905) and Kitchanga 50.4% (509/1020) of households reported at least one member subjected to violence. Displacement was reported by 39.0% of households (419/1075) in Kitchanga and 99.8% (903/905) in Masisi," one study found.[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21059195 Violence against civilians and access to health care in North Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo: three cross-sectional surveys] Many armed groups participating in the conflict have used children as active combatants. According to the report published [on 23 October 2013], almost 1,000 cases of child recruitment by armed groups were verified by MONUSCO between 1 January 2012 and 31 August 2013, predominantly in the district of [[North Kivu]].{{cite web|url=http://monusco.unmissions.org/Default.aspx?tabid=11430&ctl=Details&mid=14701&ItemID=20218&language=en-US|title=MONUSCO alarmed by child recruitment in DRC|publisher=Monusco.unmissions.org|access-date=15 October 2014}} The use of child soldiers in the Kivu conflict constitutes another example of the use of [[Child soldiers in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|child soldiers in the DRC]]. The UN has asserted that some of the girls being used as belligerents are also subjected to sexual assault, and are treated as [[sex slaves]].{{sfn|Grover|2012|p=117}} ===Sexual violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo=== {{main|Sexual violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} The Kivu conflict has created chaos and disorder in the regions of [[North Kivu|North]] and [[South Kivu]]. [[MONUSCO]] believe that widespread sexual assault has been perpetrated against women in this regions by all sides of the conflict, something which the [[UNHCR]] has condemned.{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/en-ie/news/briefing/2013/7/51f79a649/sexual-violence-rise-drcs-north-kivu.html|title=Sexual violence on the rise in DRC's North Kivu|first=United Nations High Commissioner for|last=Refugees|website=UNHCR.org|access-date=10 December 2017}} Incidents have involved the rape and sexual assault of both women and girls, included the incorporation of girls into militia forces as [[sex slaves]]. The most publicised example of sexual violence occurred in November 2012 in [[Minova]]. Having retreated to the town, FARDC troops conducted systematic rape against the women and girls over a period of three days. This resulted in widespread international condemnation, prompting the [[Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Army]] to begin an investigation in order to prosecute the perpetrators of the sexual assaults.{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/multimedia/2014/3/they-will-be-heard-therapesurvivorsofminova.html|title=They will be heard: The rape survivors of Minova|website=america.alJazeera.com|access-date=10 December 2017}} In 2014, the "Minova Trial" was conducted.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/africa/how-military-mass-rape-was-buried-in-congo/news-story/53c3e776044dcc7082ab1a6fdbb5b4c6|title=How military mass rape was buried|website=News.com.au|access-date=10 December 2017}} It was the largest rape tribunal in the nation's history. While the American Bar Association, which had an office in Goma, had identified more than 1,000 potential victims, the official list composed by the UN only had 126, of whom 56 testified at the trial. For reasons of safety, those testifying were forced to hide their faces by donning hoods. In the end, only a few junior officers were convicted. Sexual violence in the region has continued, but by 2015, funding had declined for sanctuaries for the women and protection.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/13/rape-victims-congo-world-turned-away Mark Townsend, "Revealed: how the world turned its back on rape victims of Congo"], ''The Guardian'', 13 June 2015; accessed 15 November 2017 ===Conflict minerals=== {{see also|Conflict resource#Democratic Republic of the Congo}} The role of conflict minerals in the conflict is highly debated.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2014/09/10/in-eastern-congo-economic-colonialism-in-the-guise-of-ethical-consumption/|title=In Eastern Congo, economic colonialism in the guise of ethical consumption?|first1=Christoph|last1=Vogel|first2=Ben|last2=Radley|date=10 September 2014|publisher=|access-date=10 December 2017|via=www.WashingtonPost.com}} Certain [[Non-governmental organisation|NGOs]], like the Enough Project, say that the illegal exploitation of minerals is the main cause of the ongoing violence in the Kivus.{{cite web|url=http://www.enoughproject.org/category/conflict-area/eastern-congo|title=Eastern Congo: An Action Plan to End The World's Deadliest War - The Enough Project|date=16 July 2009|website=EnoughProject.org|access-date=10 December 2017}} A United Nations report supported this view. However, many academic and independent researchers (both Congolese and international) challenge this interpretation, arguing that while conflict minerals are undoubtedly one of the many causes of violence in the region, they are most likely not the most significant and impactful one.{{cite web|url=http://www.humanosphere.org/human-rights/2014/09/conflict-mineral-law-dr-congo-harm-good-say-experts/|title=Conflict mineral law does more harm than good for Congo, say experts - Humanosphere|date=10 September 2014|website=Humanosphere.org|access-date=10 December 2017}} The most prominent and prevalent conflict mineral procured in the Kivu districts is [[gold]]. Due to its high financial value, rival militias will attack one another for control of the mineral. An investigation into conflict minerals in relation to the Kivu conflict found that "gold is now, as of 2013, the most important conflict mineral in eastern Congo, with at least 12 tons worth roughly $500 million smuggled out of the east every year." These high financial revenues were identified as the primary incentives for the mining and capture of gold. To illustrate this, this study looked at one specific rebel group, determining that "The M23 rebel group has taken over a profitable part of the conflict gold trade in the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo...It is using revenues from the illicit trade to benefit its leaders and supporters and fund its military campaign by building military alliances and networks with other armed groups that control territory around gold mines and by smuggling gold through Uganda and Burundi. [[March 23 Movement|M23]] commander [[Sultani Makenga]], who is also allegedly one of the rebels' main recruiters of [[child soldier]]s according to the U.N. Group of Experts on Congo, is at the center of the conflict gold efforts."{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201310100873.html|title=allAfrica.com: Congo-Kinshasa: Striking Gold - How M23 and Its Allies Are Infiltrating Congo's Gold Trade|work=allAfrica.com|access-date=15 October 2014}} ==See also== *[[Ituri conflict]] *[[List of conflicts in Africa]] *[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21995623 Farming the battlefield: the meanings of war, cattle and soil in South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo] *[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22416569 Impact of sexual violence on children in the Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo] *[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22929338 Militarized sexual violence in South Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo] *[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22559305 Sexual violence trends between 2004 and 2008 in South Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo] *[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22932449 Congolese community-based health program for survivors of sexual violence] *[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20691241 Appearance of konzo in South-Kivu, a wartorn area in the Democratic Republic of Congo] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last=Alfaro |first=Stephanie |year=2012 |title=Estimating human rights violations in South Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo: A population-based survey |journal=Vulnerable Children and Youth Studies |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=201–210 |doi=10.1080/17450128.2012.690574 |display-authors=etal}} *{{cite journal |last=Cox |first=T. Paul |year=2011 |title=Farming the battlefield: the meanings of war, cattle and soil in South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo |journal=Disasters |volume=36 |issue=2 |pages=233–248 |doi=10.1111/j.1467-7717.2011.01257.x }} ==External links== *[http://hrw.org/reports/2007/drc1007/ Renewed Crisis in North Kivu] (HRW) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060904172002/http://www.friendsofthecongo.org/Blog.php Friends of the Congo] History, reports, press releases, and current conditions in Congo conflict regions. *[https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2008/sc9511.doc.htm UN Security Council Report] United Nations press release, 26 November 2008 {{Democratic Republic of the Congo topics}} {{Ongoing military conflicts}} {{Years in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kivu Conflict}} [[Category:21st century in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo–Rwanda relations]] [[Category:Civil wars involving the states and peoples of Africa]] [[Category:North Kivu]] [[Category:South Kivu]] [[Category:Rebellions in Africa]] [[Category:Wars involving Angola]] [[Category:Katanga Province]] [[Category:Wars involving the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Wars involving Rwanda]] [[Category:Wars involving Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Wars involving Burundi]] [[Category:Military operations involving India]] [[Category:United Nations Force Intervention Brigade]] [[Category:Ongoing conflicts]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2016]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2017]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2018]] [[Category:Bukavu]]

revision.text: {{selfref | For link rot in Wikipedia, see [[Wikipedia:Link rot]].}} '''Link rot''' (or '''linkrot''') is the process by which [[hyperlink]]s on individual [[website]]s or the [[Internet]] in general point to [[web page]]s, [[Server (computing)|servers]] or other resources that have become permanently unavailable.{{cite journal |last1=Zittrain |first1=Jonathan |last2=Albert |first2=Kendra |last3=Lessig |first3=Lawrence |title=Perma: Scoping and Addressing the Problem of Link and Reference Rot in Legal Citations |journal=Legal Information Management |date=12 June 2014 |volume=14 |issue=2 |pages=88–99 |doi=10.1017/S1472669614000255}} Research shows that the [[half-life]] of a random webpage is two years.{{cite web|last1=Koehler|first1=Wallace|title=A longitudinal study of Web pages continued: a consideration of document persistence|url=http://www.informationr.net/ir/9-2/paper174.html|website=Information Research|accessdate=16 October 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911062629/http://www.informationr.net/ir/9-2/paper174.html|archivedate=11 September 2017|df=}}{{cite web|last1=Van der Graaf|first1=Hans|title=The half-life of a link is two year|url=http://blog.zomdir.com/2017/10/the-half-life-of-link-is-two-year.html|website=ZOMDir's blog|accessdate=16 October 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171017041901/http://blog.zomdir.com/2017/10/the-half-life-of-link-is-two-year.html|archivedate=17 October 2017|df=}} ==Terminology== Link rot is also called "link death", "link breaking" or "reference rot". A link that does not work any more is called a "broken link", "dead link", or "dangling link". Formally, this is a form of [[dangling reference]]: The target of the reference no longer exists. ==Causes== One of the most common reasons for a broken link is that the web page to that it points to no longer exists. This frequently results in a [[HTTP 404|404 error]], which indicates that the web server responded but the specific page could not be found. Another type of dead link occurs when the server that hosts the target page stops working or relocates to a new [[domain name]]. The browser may return a [[Domain Name System|DNS]] error or display a site unrelated to the content originally sought. The latter can occur when a domain name lapses and is reregistered by another party. Other reasons for broken links include: * Websites can be restructured or redesigned, or the underlying technology can be changed, altering or invalidating large numbers of inbound or internal links. * Many news sites keep articles freely accessible for only a short time period, and then move them behind a [[paywall]]. This causes a significant loss of supporting links in sites discussing news events and using media sites as references. * Content may automatically expire after a certain time period. * Content may be intentionally removed by the owner. * A server may be upgraded and code (e.g. PHP) may no longer function properly. * Links may be removed as a result of legal action or court order. * Search results from social media such as [[Facebook]] and [[Tumblr]] are prone to link rot because of frequent changes in user privacy, the deletion of accounts, search result pointing to a dynamic page that has new results that differ from the [[Cache (computing)|cached result]], or the deletion of links or photos. * Links can contain ephemeral, user-specific information such as session or login data. Because these are not universally valid, the result can be a broken link. * A link might be broken because of some form of blocking such as [[content filter]]s or [[Firewall (networking)|firewalls]]. * A website may be closed or taken down, invalidating the links which are pointing to it. * A website might change its domain name. Links pointing to the old name might then become invalid. * Dead links can occur on the authoring side, when website content is assembled from Internet sources and deployed without properly verifying the link targets. * As new private [[Generic top-level domain|gTLDs]] became popular, top-level-domains like .mcdonalds or .xperia were revoked.{{Cite web|url=https://blog.benjojo.co.uk/post/the-death-of-a-tld|title=The death of a TLD|website=blog.benjojo.co.uk|access-date=2018-07-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180726220205/https://blog.benjojo.co.uk/post/the-death-of-a-tld|archive-date=2018-07-26|dead-url=no|df=}} ==Prevalence== The [[HTTP 404|404 "Not Found"]] response is familiar to even the occasional web user.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} A number of studies have examined the prevalence of link rot on the web, in academic literature, and in [[digital library|digital libraries]].{{Cite journal|title = Decay of References to Web sites in Articles Published in General Medical Journals: Mainstream vs Small Journals|journal = Applied Clinical Informatics|date = 2013-01-01|volume = 4|issue = 4|pages = 455–64|doi = 10.4338/aci-2013-07-ra-0055|pmid = 24454575|first = P.|last = Habibzadeh|first2 = Schattauer GmbH - Publishers for Medicine and Natural|last2 = Sciences|pmc=3885908}} In a 2003 experiment, Fetterly et al. discovered that about one link out of every 200 disappeared each week from the Internet. McCown et al. (2005) discovered that half of the [[Uniform Resource Locator|URLs]] cited in [[D-Lib Magazine]] articles were no longer accessible 10 years after publication, and other studies have shown link rot in academic literature to be even worse (Spinellis, 2003, Lawrence et al., 2001). Nelson and Allen (2002) examined link rot in digital libraries and found that about 3% of the objects were no longer accessible after one year. In 2014, bookmarking site [[Pinboard (website)|Pinboard]]'s owner [[Maciej Cegłowski]] reported a “pretty steady rate” of 5% link rot per year.{{cite web | first = Maciej | last = Cegłowski | author-link = Maciej Cegłowski | title = Web Design: The First 100 Years | date = 9 September 2014 | url = http://idlewords.com/talks/web_design_first_100_years.htm | accessdate = 22 July 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150722022607/http://idlewords.com/talks/web_design_first_100_years.htm | archivedate = 22 July 2015 | df = }} A 2014 [[Harvard Law School]] study by [[Jonathan Zittrain]], Kendra Albert and [[Lawrence Lessig]], determined that approximately 50% of the URLs in U.S. Supreme Court opinions no longer link to the original information.{{Cite journal | last1 = Zittrain | first1 = Jonathan | last2 = Albert | first2 = Kendra | last3 = Lessig | first3 = Lawrence | title = Perma: Scoping and Addressing the Problem of Link and Reference Rot in Legal Citations | journal = Legal Information Management | volume = 14 | issue = 2 | pages = 88–99 | date = 12 June 2014 | df = | doi = 10.1017/S1472669614000255 }} They also found that in a selection of legal journals published between 1999 and 2011, more than 70% of the links no longer functioned as intended. A 2013 study in ''[[BMC Bioinformatics]]'' analyzed nearly 15,000 links in abstracts from [[Thomson Reuters]]' Web of Science citation index and found that the median lifespan of web pages was 9.3 years, and just 62% were archived.{{Cite journal | last1 = Hennessey | first1 = Jason | last2 = Xijin Ge | first2 = Steven | title = A Cross Disciplinary Study of Link Decay and the Effectiveness of Mitigation Techniques | journal = BMC Bioinformatics | volume = 14 | pages = S5 | date = 2013 | url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/14/S14/S5/ | accessdate = 16 January 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150121021402/http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/14/S14/S5/ | archivedate = 21 January 2015 | df = | doi = 10.1186/1471-2105-14-S14-S5 | pmid = 24266891 | pmc = 3851533 }} In August 2015 Weblock analyzed more than 180,000 links from references in the full-text corpora of three major open access publishers and found that overall 24.5% of links cited were no longer available.{{cite web | title = All-Time Weblock Report | date = August 2015 | url = https://weblock.io/report?id=all | accessdate = 12 January 2016 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304081204/https://weblock.io/report?id=all | archivedate = 4 March 2016 | df = }} ==Discovering== Discovering broken links might be done manually or automatically. Automated methods, including [[Plug-in (computing)|plug-ins]] for [[WordPress]], [[Drupal]] and other [[content management systems|content management system]] can be used to detect the presence of broken [[Uniform Resource Locator|URLs]]. An alternative is using a specific broken link checker like [[Xenu's Link Sleuth]]. However, if a URL returns an [[HTTP]] [[200 OK|200 (OK)]] response, it may be accessible, but the contents of the page could have changed and may no longer be relevant. So manual checking links seems to be a must. Some web servers also return a [[soft 404]], reporting to computers that the link works even though it doesn't. Bar-Yossef et al. (2004) {{Cite book | last1 = Bar-Yossef | first1 = Ziv | last2 = Broder | first2 = Andrei Z. | last3 = Kumar | first3 = Ravi | last4 = Tomkins | first4 = Andrew | chapter = Sic transit gloria telae: towards an understanding of the web's decay | doi = 10.1145/988672.988716 | title = Proceedings of the 13th conference on World Wide Web - WWW '04 | pages = 328 | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-1581138443 | pmid = | pmc = | df = | citeseerx = 10.1.1.1.9406 }} developed a heuristic for automatically discovering soft 404s. ==Combating== There are numerous solutions for tackling broken links: Some work to prevent them in the first place, while others try to resolve them when they have occurred. There are also numerous tools that have been developed to help combat link rot. ===Authoring=== * Carefully select and implement hyperlinks, and verify them regularly after publication. Best practices include linking to primary rather than secondary sources and prioritizing stable sites. McCown et al., 2005, suggests avoiding URL citations that point to resources on researchers' personal pages. * Always look for the most compact and direct URL available, and ensure that it's [[Clean URL|clean]], with no unnecessary information after the core of the URL.{{cite web | last = Kille | first = Leighton Walter | title = The Growing Problem of Internet "Link Rot" and Best Practices for Media and Online Publishers | publisher = Journalist's Resource, Harvard Kennedy School | date = 8 November 2014 | url = http://journalistsresource.org/studies/society/internet/website-linking-best-practices-media-online-publishers | accessdate = 16 January 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150112034707/http://journalistsresource.org/studies/society/internet/website-linking-best-practices-media-online-publishers | archivedate = 12 January 2015 | df = }} This process is often referred to as [[URL normalization]] or [[URL canonicalization]]. * Whenever possible, use [[persistent identifier]]s (URLs designed for durability) such as ARKs, [[Digital object identifier|DOIs]], Handle System references, and PURLs. * Avoid linking to [[PDF]] documents if possible. Because PDFs are documents rather than web pages, their content can change without notice, and their names are more likely to contain characters such as spaces that must be translated into safe codes for URLs. Large PDFs may also download slowly and cause a timeout error. * Avoid linking to pages deep in a website, a practice known as [[deep linking]]. * Use web archiving services (for example, [[WebCite]]) to permanently archive and retrieve cited Internet references (Eysenbach and Trudel, 2005). ===Server side=== * Never change URLs and never remove pages. If there is a reason to no longer have a page, such as a news site redacting a story, replace it with a message explaining its removal. * When URLs change, use [[URL redirection|redirection]] mechanisms such as "[[HTTP 301|301: Moved Permanently]]" to automatically refer browsers and crawlers to the new location. * [[Web content management system|Content management systems]] may offer built-in solutions to the management of links, such as updating them when content is changed or moved on a site. * [[WordPress]] guards against link rot by replacing non-canonical URLs with their [[URL canonicalization|canonical]] versions.{{cite web | last = Rønn-Jensen | first = Jesper | title = Software Eliminates User Errors And Linkrot | publisher = Justaddwater.dk | date = 2007-10-05 | url = http://justaddwater.dk/2007/10/05/blog-software-eliminates-user-errors-and-linkrot/ | accessdate = 5 October 2007 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011033526/http://justaddwater.dk/2007/10/05/blog-software-eliminates-user-errors-and-linkrot/ | archivedate = 11 October 2007 | df = }} * [[IBM]]'s [[IBM Peridot (software)|Peridot]] attempts to automatically fix broken links. * [[Permalink]]ing stops broken links by guaranteeing that the content will not move for the foreseeable future. Another form of permalinking is linking to a permalink that then redirects to the actual content, ensuring that even though the real content may be moved etc., links pointing to the resources stay intact. * Design URLs—for example, [[semantic URL]]s—such that they won't need to change when a different person takes over maintenance of a document or when different software is used on the server.{{cite web | author=Tim Berners-Lee | title=Cool URIs don't change | url=http://www.w3.org/Provider/Style/URI | date=1998 | accessdate=7 October 2013 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927221807/http://www.w3.org/Provider/Style/URI | archivedate=27 September 2013 | df= }} ===User side=== * The Linkgraph widget gets the URL of the correct page based upon the old broken URL by using historical location information. * The Google 404 Widget attempts to "guess" the correct URL, and also provides the user with a search box to find the correct page. * When a user receives a 404 response, the [[Google Toolbar]] attempts to assist the user in finding the missing page.{{cite web | last = Mueller | first = John | title = FYI on Google Toolbar's Latest Features | publisher = Google Webmaster Central Blog | date = 2007-12-14 | url = http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.com/2007/12/fyi-on-google-toolbars-latest-features.html | accessdate = 9 July 2008 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080913132848/http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.com/2007/12/fyi-on-google-toolbars-latest-features.html | archivedate = 13 September 2008 | df = }} ===Web archiving=== {{Main | Web archiving}} To combat link rot, [[Web archiving|web archivists]] are actively engaged in collecting the [[World Wide Web|Web]] or particular portions of the Web and ensuring the collection is [[Digital preservation|preserved]] in an [[archive]], such as an [[archive site]], for future researchers, historians, and the public. The goal of the [[Internet Archive]] is to maintain an archive of the entire Web, taking periodic snapshots of pages that can then be accessed for free via the [[Wayback Machine]]. In January 2013 the company announced that it had reached the milestone of 240 billion archived URLs.{{cite web |url=http://blog.archive.org/2013/01/09/updated-wayback/ |title=Wayback Machine: Now with 240,000,000,000 URLs | Internet Archive Blogs |date=2013-01-09 |accessdate=2014-04-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20170912091637/http://blog.archive.org/2013/01/09/updated-wayback/ |archivedate=2017-09-12 |df= }} [[National library|National libraries]], [[national archive]]s and other organizations are also involved in archiving culturally important Web content. Individuals may use a number of tools that allow them to archive web resources that may go missing in the future: * The "WayBack Machine", at the [[Internet Archive]],{{cite web | url=https://archive.org/ | title=Internet Archive: Digital Library of Free Books, Movies, Music & Wayback Machine | date=2001-03-10 | accessdate=7 October 2013 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970126045828/http://www.archive.org/ | archivedate=26 January 1997 | df= }} is a free website that archives old web pages. It does not archive websites whose owners have stated they do not want their website archived. * [[WebCite]], a tool specifically for scholarly authors, journal editors and publishers to permanently archive "on-demand" and retrieve cited Internet references (Eysenbach and Trudel, 2005). * [[Archive.is]], an archive site which stores snapshots of web pages. It retrieves one page at a time, but unlike WebCite, it includes [[Web 2.0]] sites such as Google Maps and Twitter. * [[Perma.cc]], which is supported by the Harvard Law School together with a broad coalition of university libraries, takes a snapshot of a URL's content and returns a permanent link. * The Hiberlink project, a collaboration between the University of Edinburgh, the Los Alamos National Laboratory and others, is working to measure “reference rot” in online academic articles, and also to what extent Web content has been archived.{{cite web | title = Hiberlink | publisher = Hiberlink.org | url = http://hiberlink.org/ | accessdate = 15 January 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150129182611/http://hiberlink.org/ | archivedate = 29 January 2015 | df = }} A related project, [[Memento Project|Memento]], has established a technical standard for accessing online content as it existed in the past.{{cite web | title = Memento: Time Travel for the Web | publisher = Memento | url = http://mementoweb.org/ | accessdate = 15 January 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150107201343/http://www.mementoweb.org/ | archivedate = 7 January 2015 | df = }} * Some [[social bookmarking]] websites allow users to make online clones of any web page on the internet, creating a copy at an independent url which remains online even if the original page goes down. * Amber, created by the [[Harvard University|Harvard]] [[Berkman Center for Internet & Society|Berkman Center]], is a tool built to fight link rot through archiving links on [[WordPress|Wordpress]] and [[Drupal]] sites to prevent web censorship and bolster content preservation.{{Cite web|title = Harvard University's Berkman Center Releases Amber, a "Mutual Aid" Tool for Bloggers & Website Owners to Help Keep the Web Available {{!}} Berkman Center|url = https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/node/99276|website = cyber.law.harvard.edu|access-date = 2016-01-28|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160202042259/https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/node/99276|archivedate = 2016-02-02|df = }} However, such preserving systems may encounter on and off service interruption so that the preserved URLs are intermittently unavailable.{{Cite journal|title = Are current archiving systems reliable enough?|journal = International Urogynecology Journal|volume = 26|issue = 10|date = 2015-07-30|issn = 0937-3462|pages = 1|doi = 10.1007/s00192-015-2805-7|pmid = 26224384|first = Parham|last = Habibzadeh}} ==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=25em}} * [[Software rot|Bit rot]] * [[Digital preservation]] * [[Internet Archive]] * [[Permalink]] * [[Persistent identifier]] * [[Slashdot effect]] * [[Web archiving]] * [[WebCite]] * [[Deletionism and inclusionism in Wikipedia]] {{div col end}} ==Further reading== ===Link rot on the Web=== * {{cite web | last = Kille | first = Leighton Walter | title = The Growing Problem of Internet "Link Rot" and Best Practices for Media and Online Publishers | publisher = Journalist's Resource, Harvard Kennedy School | date = 8 November 2014 | url = http://journalistsresource.org/studies/society/internet/website-linking-best-practices-media-online-publishers | accessdate = 16 January 2015}} * {{cite journal | first1 = Gunther | last1 = Eysenbach | first2 = Mathieu | last2 = Trudel | year = 2005 | title = Going, going, still there: Using the WebCite service to permanently archive cited web pages | doi = 10.2196/jmir.7.5.e60 | journal = Journal of Medical Internet Research | volume = 7 | issue = 5 | pages = e60 | pmid = 16403724 | pmc = 1550686}} * {{cite journal | first = Wallace | last = Koehler | year = 2004 | title = A longitudinal study of web pages continued: A consideration of document persistence | url = http://informationr.net/ir/9-2/paper174.html | journal = Information Research | volume = 9 | issue = 2 | access-date = 2006-07-18 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060803070931/http://www.informationr.net/ir/9-2/paper174.html | archive-date = 2006-08-03 | dead-url = yes | df = }} * {{cite conference | understanding of the Web's decay | booktitle = Proceedings of the 13th international conference on World Wide Web | pages = 328–337 | doi = 10.1145/988672.988716}} * {{cite conference | first1 =
